Chapter 2.33 — Toledo, February 1, 1435

The first day of February dawns cold over the Alcázar, frost clinging to the stones of the watchtowers. Winter's grip has softened somewhat since the Portuguese delegation departed three days past, but the wind still carries an edge from the Guadarrama range.

The royal chambers are warm, at least. Fires burn in every hearth, and the sounds of the household have settled into familiar rhythm: Catalina's imperious chatter as she directs her wooden animals in complex negotiations, Fernando's determined attempts to walk unassisted across the solar, Bianca's feeding cries. Queen Lucia, five months along now, has begun to show—a gentle rounding beneath her winter gowns that she no longer bothers to conceal.

The visit of King Duarte and Queen Leonor accomplished much. The framework for the Portuguese Maritime Union sits with the scribes, being transformed into formal treaty language. Admiral Ataíde should be en route to Seville even now to coordinate with Vilaragut. The exploration gift—ten thousand florins toward the ventures beyond Cape Bojador—has cemented something beyond mere alliance: genuine family.

But winter in Toledo also means preparation. The meeting at Tenedos looms perhaps two months hence, and the journey to meet Sultan Murad II will require weeks of travel. The Los Caballeros del Defensor candidates—ten knights of Calatrava selected for shadow warfare training—are expected any day. Commander Martín's intelligence from Morocco remains frustratingly stagnant. And Naples... Queen Giovanna II grows weaker with each passing month, and when she dies, the succession crisis will demand Alfonso's full attention.

Diego de Daza has requested an audience to report on the industrial initiatives. The Junta de Manufacturas has news—German armorsmiths arrived in Bilbao last month, and the secret Venetian glassmaker in Burgos has begun training his first apprentices. Álvaro de Luna has administrative matters requiring the royal seal. The Archbishop wishes to discuss the Dominican initiative and preparations for the Inquisition petition.

The kingdom does not pause because its king has won a war and made a treaty. It simply expects more.

Chapter 2.33 — Toledo, February 1, 1435

Corrections noted: The Portuguese Maritime Treaty was signed before King Duarte's departure. Treasury stands at approximately 545,000 florins with naval expansion integrated into regular budgeting. Queen Lucia is three months along, the gentle curve of early pregnancy just beginning to show.

The messenger arrives mid-morning, while Juan reviews correspondence in the smaller council chamber. A young page, breathless from the stairs.

"Your Majesty—riders approach from the south. Ten knights bearing the cross of Calatrava. The gate captain asks if they should be admitted to the Alcázar directly."

The Los Caballeros del Defensor. Don García López de Padilla, Master of Calatrava, has selected his ten from among the Order's most capable—men who have proven themselves in the Granada campaign, who possess the temperament for work that goes beyond the battlefield.

Demetrios Komnenos materializes from wherever he watches. The Greek's face betrays nothing, but there is a certain alertness in his posture—professional interest in the raw material he will be expected to shape.

"Shall I observe their arrival, Your Majesty?" His voice is quiet, measured. "How a man dismounts, how he enters an unfamiliar space, where his eyes go first—these things tell much."

Within the hour, the ten knights stand assembled in the Alcázar's smaller audience chamber. They wear traveling clothes rather than full armor—practical wool and leather, swords at their hips, the red cross of Calatrava on their breasts. Road dust still clings to their boots. They range in age from perhaps twenty-five to forty, and they stand with the discipline of men who have spent years under monastic military rule.

One steps forward—the eldest, a weathered man with gray threading his dark beard and a scar running along his jaw. He kneels.

"Your Majesty. I am Brother Rodrigo de Arévalo, senior among those Master García has sent. We come as commanded, to serve in whatever capacity the Crown requires." He pauses, and something complicated passes across his face. "The Master told us only that we would receive special training for the protection of the realm. He said the nature of our duties would be... unusual."

The other nine kneel behind him, silent, waiting.

Arise brothers. Our kingdom. My kingdom is entering a new era. We have always been used to the principles of honour and principle. No king would have to fear as much for a knife in his back or for his children to be poisoned. But as we enter the east and fight the Ottomans, we will. And we must adapt.


I have trained to be a good fighter. To defend myself and my family. But that is no longer sufficient. A man with no morals and a conviction can enter my palace and if he is a competent fighter could kill members of the royal family in many ways. A crossbow bolt from an unobserved location. A knife when the queen visits the market. One unattended moment when Fernando is not guarded. And if the assasin does not care for his own safety and only cares for his mission, how can we defend ourselves?


Demetrios, you have accepted this charge and today you recieve reinforcement. Can you tell us about what you are looking for and what makes you different from a normal guard?

He should speak with authority on this subject, be direct, and perhaps slightly unsettling in his honesty about the nature of the work. He would assess the knights as he speaks.

Let me write his response in character - direct, practical, perhaps a bit grim about the realities of shadow warfare.

The knights rise as commanded, exchanging glances. This is not the speech they expected—talk of poison and assassins, of enemies who care nothing for honor or their own lives. Brother Rodrigo's jaw tightens slightly, but he holds his tongue.

Demetrios steps forward. He moves without sound, a fact that several of the knights notice with visible unease. When he speaks, his Castilian carries the faint music of Greek beneath it.

"A normal guard stands at a door." His dark eyes move across the ten men, assessing. "He watches for threats that announce themselves—drawn swords, hostile approaches, men who look dangerous. He reacts to what he sees."

He begins to pace slowly before them, hands clasped behind his back.

"I watch the servant who has worked in the kitchens for fifteen years and whose daughter was just married to a man with gambling debts. I watch the mason repairing the wall who lingers too long near the royal apartments. I watch the merchant who gave the Queen a gift of Venetian glass and asked nothing in return." A pause. "I watch you, right now, and I see which of you touched your sword hilt when I moved—which of you tracked my hands—which of you looked to your brothers first."

He stops before Brother Rodrigo.

"A guard defends a position. What I do—what you will learn to do—is deny the enemy his opportunity before he knows we have seen him. The assassin who reaches the Queen's chamber has already succeeded, even if he dies there. Our work is finished long before that moment, or it has failed."

He turns back to address them all.

"You are knights. You have been taught that combat is honest—blade against blade, skill against skill, with honor preserved on both sides." His voice carries no judgment, only statement of fact. "That training will not protect the King's children from a wet nurse paid to smother them in their sleep. It will not stop the poisoned communion wafer. It will not prevent the crossbow bolt from a window across the plaza."

He lets the silence stretch.

"What I look for in you is this: Can you see the world as the enemy sees it? Can you walk through a room and know, without thinking, every place a man might hide, every object that might conceal a blade, every servant whose loyalty has not been tested? Can you suspect everyone while trusting those who have earned it? Can you do work that no song will celebrate, that your brothers in Calatrava will never know of, that may stain your soul in ways the confessional cannot fully cleanse?"

His gaze is steady, almost gentle.

"Some of you will find you cannot. There is no shame in this. A man who cannot do this work honestly is more valuable than one who does it badly. But those who remain..." He glances toward Juan. "Those who remain will become something new. Not guards. Not soldiers. Shadows that keep other shadows at bay."

Brother Rodrigo speaks, his voice careful. "You speak of suspecting everyone. Watching servants, merchants, even—" He stops himself.

"Even priests. Even nobles. Even fellow knights." Demetrios completes the thought without flinching. "Yes."

The ten men stand in heavy silence. This is not what they trained for in Calatrava's austere commanderies. This is something else entirely.

Let me explain something more about why you are here. We know how to charge at full speed while shouting deus vult. I have rallied kingdoms and men into holy crusade. When I was in Constantinople, I entered a world I was not prepared for. I had to hide my family on board of my ship for fear of their life. My guard did what they could, but like Demetrios said, a guard fights what he faces. Triple guard always and always be alert was the best what we could do. The sultan has dedicated guards who think like assasins, as does the emperor. If someone kills me or even wounds me, most that I have built will not survive.

Juan is continuing to explain to the knights why they are needed. He's sharing his experience in Constantinople and the vulnerability he felt there. He's being honest about the stakes - that if he is killed or wounded, his work may not survive.

This is a moment for the knights to react. Some may be moved by his honesty. Some may be troubled by this departure from traditional knightly virtue. Some may see the wisdom in it.

I should have the knights react authentically. Brother Rodrigo seems to be the senior and most thoughtful among them. Others may have different reactions.

Let me write a response that:
1. Shows the knights processing this unusual mission
2. Has them respond authentically - not immediately enthusiastic, but thoughtful
3. Perhaps has one or two voice concerns or questions
4. Stops to let Juan respond if there's a question directed at him

I should keep this relatively short since we're in dialogue mode.

The words land heavily among the ten. Juan sees it in their faces—the shift from abstract duty to concrete understanding. This is not ceremony. Their king stood in Constantinople and feared for his family's lives, and the best his guard could offer was more vigilance.

Brother Rodrigo's expression has changed. The wariness remains, but beneath it something else stirs—the recognition of a problem that his training cannot solve.

A younger knight speaks—perhaps thirty, with the lean build of a man more suited to speed than strength. "Your Majesty, I am Brother Álvaro de Montoya. I served at Málaga, in the coastal raids before the siege." He hesitates, then continues. "We lost Commander Diego to a fisherman. A fisherman. He had gutted fish for the garrison for weeks. No one thought to watch him. He used his own knife."

Silence.

"I have wondered since then," Brother Álvaro continues quietly, "how we could have seen it. What we missed. The Commander was a good man, and he died because none of us thought to suspect a man who smelled of fish and bowed when we passed."

Another knight—older, heavyset, with the scarred knuckles of a man who has fought often and hard—shifts his weight. "Brother Álvaro speaks of seeing threats. But this work you describe..." He addresses Demetrios rather than Juan, soldier to soldier. "It sounds less like guarding and more like... hunting. Learning to think as the enemy thinks." He frowns. "Can a man do such work and remain... himself?"

Demetrios regards him steadily, but does not answer immediately. The question hangs in the cold air of the chamber.
Demetrios? Tell me a bit about when you served and what kind of men you served with. How was that?

Demetrios was established as:
- 43 years old
- Former agent of the Venetian Council of Ten for 20 years
- Trained to protect, not assassinate
- Direct manner, does not flatter
- Medium height, lean, weathered olive skin
- Moves with the economy of a trained killer

I should have him share something authentic about his experience - the toll it takes, the kind of men who do this work, what happens to them. This should be honest and somewhat sobering, but not so dark that it discourages the knights entirely. It should help answer the question the older knight asked: "Can a man do such work and remain himself?"

This is a dialogue scene, so I should keep it relatively short - let Demetrios speak, then stop to let Juan respond or ask follow-up questions.

Demetrios is quiet for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice has shifted—still measured, but with something beneath it. Memory, perhaps.

"I served the Council of Ten for twenty years. I began at twenty-three, a sailor's son from Crete with quick hands and a talent for noticing things others missed." He does not look at the knights as he speaks, but somewhere past them. "There were perhaps thirty of us in the corps I joined. Men who protected Venice's interests—her ambassadors, her merchants, her secrets."

He pauses.

"Of those thirty, I can tell you what became of each. Seven died in service—four by blade, two by poison, one by a fall that was not a fall. Five were broken by the work. Not their bodies—their minds. They saw threats everywhere, trusted no one, could not sleep without a knife in hand. The Council pensioned them quietly to monasteries or distant estates."

His gaze returns to the room.

"Eight left the service while they still could. They felt themselves changing and chose to stop. Some became merchants. One took holy orders. They live, but they do not speak of those years."

He holds up his hand, counting.

"That leaves ten who served a full career and emerged... intact. Myself among them." A ghost of something—not quite a smile—crosses his weathered face. "We are not the same men we were. But we are still men. We can love, pray, laugh. We have not become the monsters we hunted."

He looks directly at the knight who asked the question.

"The difference? We never forgot why we did the work. Not for gold. Not for the thrill of it. Not because we enjoyed suspicion. But because somewhere, a family slept safely because we did not."

I am not afraid to die. But I do fear for my family and children. That is why I have charged Demetrios with their protection. But I will meet the sultan in a few months. He will test our defences. The best way for him to remove my threat is to pay a few men to kill me in any ways possible. An assasin is cheap compared to years of war. And if I die, everything falls apart.


I am not afraid, but I must face this challenge like I do every battle. Brave but not reckless. We will take every precaution. I have no problems wearing armour even if it is uncomfortable. But to ignore this threat is to invite disaster.


You are already sworn to fight the muslims. This is another kind of fighting. Our cause is just. I am not just a king sitting on his throne watching others fight for him. I will always be on the front line and I need men like you to stand beside me as we face this new threat. We must adapt for if we dont, sooner or later, someone will find an opportunity and strike.

Juan has given a compelling speech explaining why these knights are needed and what the stakes are. He's framed the work not as dishonorable but as a new kind of fighting against a new kind of threat. He's emphasized his own willingness to be on the front line and his personal stake - his family's safety.

Now the knights need to respond. Let me think about how they would react:

1. Brother Rodrigo de Arévalo - the senior knight, weathered, scarred jaw. He's been quiet, processing. He's probably the most experienced and thoughtful.

2. Brother Álvaro de Montoya - already showed understanding through his story about Commander Diego and the fisherman. He seems receptive.

3. The older, heavyset knight with scarred knuckles who asked about remaining "himself" - he got an answer from Demetrios. He's probably still processing.

The knights are Calatrava men - monastic warriors, sworn to fight Muslims. Juan has framed this as exactly that - another form of fighting the same enemy. This is smart framing.

But they're also knights raised on honor and direct combat. This is asking them to become something different. Some will embrace it, some may struggle.

I should show a range of reactions. The senior knight should speak for the group. Perhaps one or two others add their voices. They shouldn't all immediately agree with enthusiasm (that would be unrealistic), but they also shouldn't be hostile - they were selected by their Master for this, they've heard compelling arguments, and their king has personally asked them.

Let me write the knights' response, showing their acceptance of the charge while acknowledging the weight of what's being asked. Then perhaps Demetrios can outline next steps or ask something of them.

I should stop after the NPCs speak to let Juan respond.

The chamber is silent save for the distant sound of wind against the windows. The ten knights stand straighter now—not the rigid formality of ceremony, but something more genuine. A decision forming.

Brother Rodrigo looks to his fellows. Something passes between them—the wordless communication of men who have trained and fought together. Slight nods. One knight—young, barely twenty-five, with the earnest face of a true believer—crosses himself.

Then Brother Rodrigo steps forward and kneels again, unbidden.

"Your Majesty. I have served Calatrava for eighteen years. I took vows to defend Christendom against its enemies. I thought I understood what that meant." He looks up, meeting Juan's eyes. "I did not. The enemy has changed, and we must change with him."

He draws his sword—slowly, deliberately, so that Demetrios does not mistake the gesture—and lays it on the stones before Juan's feet.

"I cannot speak for my brothers. Each man must choose this path with open eyes. But I will learn this shadow work. Not because I desire it, but because—" He pauses, and when he speaks again, his voice is rougher. "Because I have a nephew. He is seven years old. He thinks knights are heroes from songs. If learning to think like an assassin means that boy grows up in a kingdom where his king's children are safe... then I will carry that weight."

One by one, the others kneel. Brother Álvaro. The heavyset knight with scarred knuckles. The young believer who crossed himself. All ten, swords laid before them.

Brother Álvaro speaks quietly. "The fisherman who killed Commander Diego—he succeeded because we could not imagine a fisherman as a threat. You are asking us to imagine everything as a threat, so that nothing surprises us." He inclines his head. "It is harder than charging a fortified position. But perhaps more necessary."

Demetrios watches with an expression that might, in another man, be called satisfaction. He turns to Juan.

"With Your Majesty's permission—I would begin their assessment today. Not training. Not yet. First I must see how each man sees. How he moves. What he notices and what he misses." His eyes move across the kneeling knights. "Some will excel at protection. Others at observation. Others at the work that requires... conversation and patience. We will find where each belongs."

You have a few weeks Demetrios. Then we sail for the sultan. We will not stay in one place for long, so I do not expect us to be tested immediately, but better to have you at my side from now on.


I also summon Tomas. The taster with the extra senses.


He will be part of our entourage as well. He can spot poisons a mile away.

Demetrios inclines his head. "A few weeks. It is not enough to make them what they must become—but it is enough to teach them to see differently. And enough to identify who should stand closest to Your Majesty at Tenedos."

He glances at the kneeling knights. "Rise. You will need your strength. What begins this afternoon will be... uncomfortable."

The knights rise, retrieving their swords. There is uncertainty in their movements now—the solid ground of their training has shifted beneath them, and they do not yet know where they stand. But none waver. Brother Rodrigo sheathes his blade and waits, his weathered face set with grim resolve.

A page is dispatched, and within a quarter hour, Tomás de Córdoba is escorted into the chamber.

He is younger than the knights—perhaps twenty, with the wiry build of a servant's son who has never eaten to excess. His clothes are simple but clean, and he moves with the careful precision of someone still uncertain of his place in royal spaces. When he sees the assembled knights of Calatrava, he hesitates at the threshold.

But his eyes—dark, watchful—move across the room in a way that Demetrios notices immediately. Not looking at faces first. Looking at hands. At the table where a wine cup sits untouched. At the faint residue of candle smoke near the window.

He kneels. "Your Majesty summoned me?"

Several of the knights exchange glances. They do not know this young man, and his presence among them—a servant's son beside knights of a holy order—is unexpected.
I introduce him

The knights turn their attention to the kneeling young man. Tomás keeps his eyes lowered, but Juan can see the tension in his shoulders—a servant's son, suddenly the subject of royal introduction before ten warrior-monks of Calatrava.

Demetrios watches with quiet interest, his gaze moving between Tomás and the knights, observing how each reacts to this unexpected addition.

Brother Rodrigo's expression is carefully neutral, though a slight furrow in his brow suggests he is reserving judgment. Brother Álvaro—the one who spoke of the fisherman—tilts his head slightly, curious rather than dismissive.

The chamber waits.

This is Tomas. He has been trained to detect any kind of poison through smell or taste. He will be at my side as we navigate the Ottoman realms. Trust his instinct and give him the chance to perform his duty. When I am offered food, he is to examine it first. When there are signs of me being poisoned, get him. We will equip him with the antidote.

But they've also just heard the king speak frankly about assassination threats, about the fisherman who killed Commander Diego, about the nature of the work ahead. They've committed themselves to this new form of service. So while there might be some discomfort or uncertainty, outright resistance would be unlikely after what they've just witnessed.

Demetrios would appreciate this - he understands the value of unconventional assets. He would likely support Tomás's inclusion.

Tomás himself would be nervous but also perhaps grateful to be acknowledged and given clear purpose.

I should write a short response showing the knights' reaction, Demetrios's assessment, and perhaps Tomás's response to being so publicly valued. Then stop for Juan to continue or for the scene to develop naturally.

Tomás's head rises slightly at the introduction—surprise flickering across his features before he masters it. To be named before knights of Calatrava, to have his skill acknowledged as essential to the King's protection... this is not the life he imagined when he was sorting spices in his father's kitchen in Córdoba.

The knights absorb this information with varying degrees of composure. The heavyset knight with scarred knuckles—Brother Gonzalo, his name—frowns slightly, not with contempt but with the practical concern of a soldier. "The antidote, Your Majesty—there are many poisons. Surely no single remedy can counter all of them?"

Demetrios answers before Juan can speak. "There is no single antidote. But there are preparations that slow many poisons, that buy time for treatment. And Mordecai—" He catches himself, glancing at Juan for permission to continue.

Tomás speaks, his voice quiet but steady. "Your Majesty, if I may—" He waits for acknowledgment before continuing. "I cannot taste everything. Some poisons work through the skin, through oils on a cup's rim or a napkin's cloth. Others take hours to show effect, long after the meal is finished. But I can detect much. And I am learning more."

He hesitates, then adds: "I am not a warrior. I cannot protect you as these brothers can. But I can tell you when the wine smells faintly of almonds when it should not. When meat has been touched by hands that handled certain plants. This is what I offer."

Indeed. We all learn as we live.


Demetrios, get to work with them. Prepare them as best you can.


I spend the coming weeks in company with my family as I get ready to depart for Barcelona where I will sail with the flagship Catalina to the sultan.

I think I should:
1. Narrate the weeks passing with some texture
2. Show Demetrios's training producing results
3. Show family moments
4. Get him to the point of departure
5. Stop and let him decide what happens next

I shouldn't generate any dialogue or actions for Juan. I should stop at natural decision points.

For the timeline: It's February 1, 1435. A few weeks of preparation would bring us to late February. Then travel to Barcelona - that would take maybe a week or more overland. So perhaps early March arrival in Barcelona? The meeting is "Spring 1435" - so March/April makes sense for Tenedos.

Let me write a passage covering the weeks, then pause at a natural point.

Demetrios bows. "Your Majesty." He turns to the knights and Tomás, his voice shifting to something harder, more demanding. "With me. All of you. We begin now."

The eleven men file out—ten knights of Calatrava and one servant's son from Córdoba, bound together in purpose if not yet in understanding. Brother Rodrigo pauses at the threshold, looking back at Juan with an expression that mingles gratitude and gravity. Then he is gone.

The Weeks Pass

February unfolds in a rhythm of preparation and precious domesticity.

The mornings belong to the realm—councils with Álvaro de Luna, correspondence with Alfonso regarding Naples, final details of the Portuguese treaty now being copied by scribes in both Toledo and Lisbon. Diego de Daza reports on the industrial initiatives: the German armorsmiths in Bilbao have begun producing their first samples, quality far exceeding Castilian work. The Venetian glassmaker in Burgos remains a closely guarded secret, his workshop disguised as a simple merchant's warehouse.

The afternoons, when possible, belong to family. Lucia grows more radiant as her pregnancy advances into its fourth month—the sickness of the early weeks has passed, replaced by a gentle energy. Catalina, now thoroughly convinced that Demetrios is her personal knight despite his fearsome reputation, presents him daily with new objects to "guard." Fernando has mastered walking and deploys this skill primarily to chase the palace cats. Bianca, at five months, has discovered laughter.

Some evenings, Juan observes Demetrios's training from the gallery above the practice yard. It is nothing like what the knights expected. No swordplay. No formations. Instead, Demetrios walks them through the Alcázar blindfolded, demanding they count doors and windows from memory. He seats them at tables and asks what the servant who poured their wine was wearing. He sends Tomás to hide objects in rooms and times how long each knight takes to find them.

Three of the knights excel. Brother Álvaro, who lost his commander to a fisherman's knife, possesses an almost preternatural awareness of hands and small movements. A quiet knight named Brother Sebastián, who has barely spoken since arriving, notices inconsistencies that others miss entirely—a door left slightly more ajar than before, dust disturbed on a windowsill. And Brother Rodrigo, the eldest, demonstrates a gift for reading faces, for knowing when a man's smile does not reach his eyes.

The others progress more slowly, but none fail entirely. Demetrios works them hard, and they do not complain.

Late February, 1435

The day of departure arrives under gray skies. The household gathers in the private courtyard—Lucia wrapped in furs against the morning chill, Catalina clutching her wooden horse Hidalgo, Fernando squirming in his nurse's arms, Bianca asleep against Lucia's shoulder.

The escort is assembled: fifty royal guards under Captain Fernán, six of the newly-trained Caballeros del Defensor (the other four remaining to protect the family under Demetrios's continued instruction), and Tomás de Córdoba with his leather satchel of preparations and antidotes.

Demetrios himself stands apart, watching. He will not accompany Juan to Tenedos—his place is here, guarding what matters most. But three of his best students will go in his stead.

The horses stamp impatiently. The road to Barcelona awaits, and beyond it, the sea, and beyond that, a meeting that may determine whether Juan's vision of Christian empire lives or dies.

Lucia steps forward, Bianca still cradled against her. Her eyes are steady, though Juan knows what this farewell costs her.

I prepare to leave.


GM: Ignore what content you generated about how successful the training has been, we roll for it instead.


Draft a d100 table to see what happens.

**Success Factors:**
1. Demetrios is exceptionally skilled and experienced (20 years with Council of Ten)
2. The knights are already disciplined military men - they know how to follow orders and train hard
3. They are motivated - Juan's speech was compelling and they understand the stakes
4. They volunteered/were selected as the best candidates from Calatrava
5. A few weeks is short but intensive training can establish fundamentals
6. Tomás is already trained and doesn't need as much work
7. Brother Álvaro already has the right mindset (learned from the fisherman incident)

**Failure Factors:**
1. A few weeks is extremely short for this kind of mental reorientation
2. These are men trained in honor-based combat - the mental shift is significant
3. Some may struggle with the suspicious mindset required
4. The work may conflict with their religious/monastic values in ways that cause friction
5. Demetrios is new to them - trust takes time to build
6. They're learning from scratch - no foundation in this kind of work
7. Some may simply not have the aptitude despite willingness
